readingPart.reading:
astrocytedendriteneuron
axonmeningesoligodendroglial cell
cauda equinamyelin sheathplexus
cerebral cortex

questionContent.questionText:
1. microscopic fiber leading from the cell body that carries the nervous impulse along a nerve cell [axon]

2. large, interlacing network of nerves [plexus]

3. three protective membranes surrounding the brain and spinal cord [meninges]

4. microscopic branching fiber of a nerve cell that is the first part to receive the nervous impulse [dendrite]

5. outer region of the largest part of the brain; composed of gray matter [cerebral cortex]

6. glial cell that transports water and salts between capillaries and nerve cells [astrocyte]

7. glial cell that produces myelin [oligodendroglial cell]

8. a nerve cell that transmits a nerve impulse [neuron]

9. collection of spinal nerves below the end of the spinal cord at the level of the second lumbar vertebra [cauda equina]

10. fatty tissue that surrounds the axon of a nerve cell [myelin sheath]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed neurologic structures with the descriptions/definitions that follow.

readingPart.reading: outermost meningeal layer surrounding the brain and spinal cord
brain and the spinal cord
nerves outside the brain and spinal cord; cranial, spinal, and autonomic nerves
middle meningeal membrane surrounding the brain and spinal cord
part of the brain below the thalamus; controls sleep, appetite, body temperature, and secretions from the pituitary gland
space through which a nervous impulse is transmitted from a nerve cell to another nerve cell or to a muscle or gland cell
autonomic nerves that influence body functions involuntarily in times of stress
part of the brain just above the spinal cord that controls breathing, heartbeat, and the size of blood vessels
part of the brain anterior to the cerebellum and between the medulla and the upper parts of the brain; connects these parts of the brain
posterior part of the brain that coordinates voluntary muscle movements
part of the brain below the cerebrum; relay center that conducts impulses between the spinal cord and the cerebrum
canals in the interior of the brain that are filled with CSF
lower portion of the brain that connects the cerebrum with the spinal cord (includes the pons and the medulla)
largest part of the brain; controls voluntary muscle movement, vision, speech, hearing, thought, memory
collection of nerve cell bodies outside the brain and spinal cord

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
glial cellsneurotransmittersensory nerves
gyriparenchymal cellsubarachnoid space
motor nervespia matersulci

questionContent.questionText:
1. innermost meningeal membrane [pia mater]

2. carry messages away from (efferent) the brain and spinal cord to muscles and glands [motor nerves]

3. carry messages toward (afferent) the brain and spinal cord from receptors [sensory nerves]

4. grooves in the cerebral cortex [sulci]

5. contains cerebrospinal fluid [subarachnoid space]

6. elevations in the cerebral cortex [gyri]

7. chemical that is released at the end of a nerve cell and stimulates or inhibits another cell (example: acetylcholine) [neurotransmitter]

8. essential cell of the nervous system; a neuron [parenchymal cell]

9. connective and supportive (stromal) tissue [glial cells]

instructions.instructions: Match the following terms with the meanings or associated terms below.

questionContent.questionText:
1. disease of the brain [encephalopathy/myelopathy]

2. part of the brain that controls muscular coordination and balance [cerebellum/cerebrum]

3. collection of blood above the dura mater [epidural hematoma/subdural hematoma]

4. inflammation of the pia and arachnoid membranes [leptomeningitis/causalgia]

5. condition of absence of a brain [anencephaly/hypalgesia]

6. inflammation of the gray matter of the spinal cord [poliomyelitis/polyneuritis]

7. pertaining to the membranes around the brain and spinal cord [meningeal/cerebellopontine]

8. disease of nerve roots (of spinal nerves) [radiculopathy/neuropathy]

9. hernia of the spinal cord and meninges [myelomeningocele/meningioma]

10. pertaining to the tenth cranial nerve [vagal/thalamic]

instructions.instructions: Select the correct term from the dropdown for the given definition.

readingPart.reading: outer region of the cerebrum (contains gray matter)
pertaining to within a sheath through the meninges and into the subarachnoid space
inflammation of many nerves
pertaining to the thalamus
disease of the spinal cord
tumor of the meninges
tumor of neuroglial cells (a brain tumor)
mass of blood below the dura mater (outermost meningeal membrane)

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
aphasiadyslexianarcolepsy
ataxiahemiparesisneurasthenia
bradykinesiahyperesthesiaparaplegia
causalgiamotor apraxiasyncope

questionContent.questionText:
1. reading disorder [dyslexia]

2. condition of decreased coordination [ataxia]

3. condition of slow movement [bradykinesia]

4. condition of increased sensation [hyperesthesia]

5. seizure of sleep; uncontrollable compulsion to sleep [narcolepsy]

6. difficulty with speech [aphasia]

7. inability to perform a task [motor apraxia]

8. weakness in the right or left half of the body [hemiparesis]

9. severe burning pain due to nerve injury [causalgia]

10. paralysis in the lower part of the body [paraplegia]

11. fainting [syncope]

12. nervous exhaustion (lack of strength) and fatigue [neurasthenia]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed neurologic symptoms with the definitions/descriptions that follow.

readingPart.reading: lack of sensitivity to pain
difficulty in speaking (patient cannot articulate words but can understand speech and knows what she or he wants to say)
weakness and partial loss of movement
paralysis in all four extremities (damage is to the cervical part of the spinal cord)
no strength (weakness)
pertaining to coma (loss of consciousness from which the patient cannot be aroused)
condition of abnormal sensations (prickling, tingling, burning)
excessive movement
condition of no sensation or nervous feeling
severe burning pain from injury to peripheral nerves
pertaining to without movement
diminished sensation to pain
impairment of the ability to perform voluntary movements
recurrent vascular headache with severe pain of unilateral onset and photophobia (sensitivity to light)

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms.

readingPart.reading:
Alzheimer diseaseHuntington diseasemyasthenia gravis
amyotrophic lateral sclerosishydrocephalusParkinson disease
Bell palsymultiple sclerosismyelomeningocele
epilepsy

questionContent.questionText:
1. Destruction of myelin sheath (demyelination) and its replacement by hard plaques: [multiple sclerosis]

2. Sudden, transient disturbances of brain function cause seizures : [epilepsy]

3. The spinal column is imperfectly joined (a split in a vertebra occurs), and part of the meninges and spinal cord can herniate out of the spinal cavity: [myelomeningocele]

4. Atrophy of muscles and paralysis caused by damage to motor neurons in the spinal cord and brainstem: [amyotrophic lateral sclerosis]

5. Patient displays bizarre, abrupt, involuntary, dance -like movements, as well as decline in mental functions: [Huntington disease]

6. Cerebrospinal fluid accumulates in the head (in the ventricles of the brain): [hydrocephalus]

7. Loss of muscle strength due to the inability of a neurotransmitter (acetylcholine) to transmit impulses from nerve cells to muscle cells: [myasthenia gravis]

8. Degeneration of nerves in the basal ganglia occurring in later life, leading to tremors, shuffling gait, and muscle stiffness; dopamine (neurotransmitter) is deficient in the brain: [Parkinson disease]

9. Deterioration of mental capacity (dementia) ; autopsy shows cerebral cortex atrophy, widening of cerebral sulci, and microscopic neurofibrillary tangles: [Alzheimer disease]

10. Unilateral facial paralysis: [Bell palsy]

instructions.instructions: Match the listed neurologic pathology terms with the descriptions that follow. The terms in boldface are clues!

readingPart.reading: tumor of neuroglial brain cells (astrocytes)
inflammation of the meninges (bacterial infection with pus formation)
involuntary spasmodic, twitching movements (tics), uncontrollable vocal sounds, and inappropriate words
bruising of brain tissue as a result of direct trauma to the head
disruption of the normal blood supply to the brain; stroke or cerebral infarction
traumatic brain injury caused by a blow to the head
neurologic condition caused by infection with herpes zoster virus; blisters form along the course of peripheral nerves
blockage of a blood vessel in the cerebrum caused by material from another part of the body that suddenly occludes the vessel
blockage of a blood vessel in the cerebrum caused by the formation of a clot within the vessel
collection of blood in the brain (can cause a stroke)
widening of a blood vessel (artery) in the cerebrum; the aneurysm can burst and lead to a CVA
brain disease (dementia and encephalitis) caused by infection with AIDS virus

instructions.instructions: Give the meanings of the following terms for abnormal conditions.

questionContent.questionText:
1. ataxia [uncoordinated gait]

2. aura [peculiar sensation experienced by patient before onset of seizure]

3. transient ischemic attack [blood flow to the brain stops for a brief period of time]

4. tonic-clonic seizure [major epileptic seizure; ictal event]

5. herpes zoster [virus that causes chickenpox and shingles]

6. palliative [relieving, but not curing]

7. dopamine [neurotransmitter]

8. occlusion [blockage]

9. absence seizure [minor epileptic seizure]

10. glioblastoma multiforme [malignant brain tumor of immature glial cells]

instructions.instructions: Match the term with its description or meaning from the dropdown.

readingPart.reading: use of magnetic waves to create an image (in frontal, transverse, or sagittal plane) of the brain
an instrument (stereotactic) is fixed onto the skull and locates a target by three-dimensional measurement; gamma radiation or proton beams are used to treat deep brain lesions

instructions.instructions: Describe what happens in the following two procedures.

readingPart.reading:
analgesiaataxianeurasthenia
anesthesiadyskinesiaparesis
aphasiadyslexiaparesthesia
apraxiahyperkinesia

questionContent.questionText:
1. lack of nerve strength [neurasthenia]

2. inability to speak [aphasia]

3. inability to perform purposeful actions [apraxia]

4. condition of insensitivity to pain [analgesia]

5. condition of loss of sensation [anesthesia]

6. sensations of tingling, numbness, or “pins and needles” [paresthesia]

7. lack of coordination [ataxia]

8. excessive movement [hyperkinesia]

9. abnormal, involuntary, spasmodic movements [dyskinesia]

10. developmental reading disorder [dyslexia]

11. partial paralysis [paresis]

instructions.instructions: Match these easily confused terms for neurologic pathology with the meanings/descriptions that follow.

questionContent.questionText:
1. EEG [electroencephalography]
2. PET [positron emission tomography]
3. AFP [alpha-fetoprotein]
4. MS [multiple sclerosis]
5. MRI [magnetic resonance imaging]
6. LP [lumbar puncture]
7. CVA [cerebrovascular accident]
8. AD [Alzheimer disease]
9. TIA [transient ischemic attack]
10. CSF [cerebrospinal fluid]

1. Procedure to diagnose abnormal electrical activity in the brain.
[electroencephalography]
2. Radioactive materials, such as glucose, are taken up by the brain, and images recorded.
[positron emission tomography]
3. High levels in amniotic fluid and maternal blood are associated with spina bifida.
[alpha-fetoprotein]
4. Destruction of the myelin sheath in the CNS occurs with plaques of hard scar tissue.
[multiple sclerosis]
5. Diagnostic procedure that allows excellent visualization of soft tissue in the brain.
[magnetic resonance imaging]
6. Intrathecal medications can be administered through this procedure.
[lumbar puncture]
7. Stroke; embolus, hemorrhage, and thrombosis are etiologic factors.
[cerebrovascular accident]
8. Gradually progressive dementia.
[Alzheimer disease]
9. Neurologic symptoms and/or signs due to temporary interference of blood supply to the brain.
[transient ischemic attack]
10. This fluid is analyzed for abnormal blood cells, chemicals, and protein.
[cerebrospinal fluid]

instructions.instructions: From the dropdown, select the term that best matches the description.

questionContent.questionText:
1. Maria had such severe headaches that she could find relief only with strong analgesics. Her condition of [migraine/spina bifida/epileps] was debilitating.

2. Paul was in a coma after his high-speed car accident. His physicians were concerned that he had suffered a [contusion and subdural hematoma/palsy, myelomeningocele] as a result of the accident.

3. Dick went to the emergency department complaining of dizziness, nausea, and headache. The physician, suspecting increased ICP, prescribed corticosteroids, and Dick ’ s symptoms disappeared. They returned, however, when the steroids were discontinued. A/an [MRI study of the brain/electroencephalogram/CSF analysis] revealed a large brain lesion. It was removed surgically and determined to be a/an [glioblastoma multiforme/embolus/migraine].

4. Dorothy felt weakness in her hand and numbness in her arm, and noticed blurred vision, all signs of [TIA/herpes zoster/meningitis] . Her physician requested[MRA/myelography/lumbar puncture] to assess any damage to cerebral blood vessels and possible stroke.

5. When Bill noticed ptosis and muscle weakness in his face, he reported these symptoms to his doctor. The doctor diagnosed his condition as [myasthenia gravis/Tourette syndrome/Huntington disease] and prescribed [anticholinesterase drugs/dopamine/anticonvulsants] , which relieved his symptoms.

6. To rule out bacterial [meningitis/epilepsy/encephalomalacia] , Dr. Phillips, a pediatrician, requested that a/an [LP/EEG/PET scan] be performed on the febrile (feverish) child.

7. Eight-year-old Barry reversed his letters and had difficulty learning to read and write words. His family physician diagnosed his problem as [dyslexia/aphasia/ataxia] .

8. After his head hit the steering wheel during a recent automobile accident, Clark noticed [hemiparesis/paraplegia/hyperesthesia] on the left side of his body. A head CT scan revealed [subdural hematoma/narcolepsy/neurasthenia] .

9. For her 35th birthday, Elizabeth’s husband threw her a surprise party. She was so startled by the crowd that she experienced a weakness of muscles and loss of consciousness. Friends placed her on her back in a horizontal position with her head low to improve blood flow to her brain. She soon recovered from her [syncopal/myoneural/hyperkinetic] episode.

10. Near his 65th birthday, Edward began having difficulty remembering recent events. Over the next 5 years, he developed [dementia/dyslexia/seizures] and was diagnosed with [Alzheimer disease/multiple sclerosis/myasthenia gravis] .

11. Elderly Mrs. Smith had been taking an antipsychotic drug for 5 years when she began exhibiting lip smacking and darting movements of her tongue. Her doctor described her condition as [tardive dyskinesia/radiculitis/hemiparesis] and discontinued her drug. The condition, acquired after use of the drug, would be considered[iatrogenic/congenital/ictal] .

instructions.instructions: Select the terms from the dropdown that complete the meanings of the sentences.

questionContent.questionText:
1. part of the brain that controls sleep, appetite, temperature, and secretions of the pituitary gland: hypo[thalamus]

2. pertaining to fainting: syn[copal]

3. abnormal tingling sensations: par[esthesias]

4. slight paralysis: par[esis]

5. inflammation of a spinal nerve root: [radicul]itis

6. inability to speak correctly: a[phasia]

7. movements and behavior that are not purposeful: a[praxia]

8. lack of muscular coordination: a[taxia]

9. developmental reading disorder: dys[lexia]

10. excessive movement: hyper[kinesis]

11. paralysis in one half (right or left) of the body: [hemi]plegia

12. paralysis in the lower half of the body: [para]plegia

13. paralysis in all four limbs: [quadri]plegia

14. nervous exhaustion and fatigue: neur[asthenia]

instructions.instructions: Complete the spelling of the following terms based on their meanings.
